Metro is a series I first heard about back when Metro Exodus was blowing up. At the time, I didn‚Äôt even plan to touch the earlier games ‚Äî I just wanted to play Exodus and be done with it. But when they gave away the first game for free, I figured, ‚ÄúAlright, why not?‚Äù ‚Ä¶and then postponed it for ages anyway.

When I finally launched it, I had no idea what was going on at first ‚Äî why we‚Äôre in the Metro, how we ended up there, what the hell happened. But as the story goes on, everything gets explained so naturally and so well that it just pulls you in. The atmosphere is amazing: dark, creepy, heavy. You really feel what the main character feels, and it stops being ‚Äújust another shooter‚Äù ‚Äî it genuinely feels like you are stuck in this world crawling with mutants ready to tear you or your friends apart. And the moments when Artyom is left completely alone, and you have to deal with everything by yourself‚Ä¶ those gave me goosebumps.

The graphics also blew me away ‚Äî for a game from that year, it looks insanely good. I honestly have nothing to complain about.

And the world itself feels alive. Wherever you go, you can tell that people are actually living there. Someone‚Äôs doing something, someone‚Äôs talking, someone‚Äôs sleeping; you can knock on a random door and someone will respond ‚Äî and if you keep knocking, the responses change. NPCs actually react when you approach them instead of staring blankly like in most games. It‚Äôs just‚Ä¶ really well done.

The weapon system is also great: upgrades, swapping gear, selling and buying ammo ‚Äî everything feels thoughtful. You decide what to keep, what to sell, what to upgrade, and what to spend your hard-earned bullets on.

Overall ‚Äî I absolutely recommend this game, and honestly the whole Metro series.

Metro 2033 Redux ‚Äî A Dark, Atmospheric Descent Into Survival

Metro 2033 Redux takes players deep into the haunting tunnels beneath post-apocalyptic Moscow, where humanity struggles to survive against mutants, radiation, and the darkness itself. From the very beginning, the game establishes an oppressive, immersive atmosphere that pulls you into its bleak yet captivating world.

The game delivers tense, story-driven FPS gameplay. Stealth, resource management, and careful exploration are essential, as ammunition and supplies are scarce. Every encounter feels weighty and dangerous, forcing you to think before you act. Whether you‚Äôre sneaking past human factions or fighting off mutated horrors, the tension never fades.

Narrative and world-building are standout features. Through atmospheric environments, somber characters, and gripping storytelling, Metro 2033 creates a sense of desperation and hope in equal measure. Audio logs, conversations, and environmental details gradually reveal a world still clinging to life despite overwhelming odds.

Redux enhancements bring improved visuals, smoother performance, and polished mechanics. Lighting and textures are sharper, controls are more responsive, and the overall experience feels more refined while staying true to the original‚Äôs tone and emotional impact.

[h3]Final Verdict:[/h3]
Metro 2033 Redux is a gripping and atmospheric survival shooter that combines intense gameplay with exceptional storytelling. Whether you're revisiting the tunnels or experiencing them for the first time, it remains a must-play for fans of post-apocalyptic adventures.

Metro 2033 Redux is the enhanced and significantly improved version of the original 2010 post-apocalyptic FPS, later rebuilt and released by DeepSilver in 2014. The game is based on Dmitry Glukhovsky‚Äôs novel of the same name and is widely considered a faithful adaptation.

Redux features noticeably better graphics, detailed textures, dynamic lighting, and stronger atmospheric effects. The underground tunnels feel more claustrophobic, and the surface areas look even more desolate. Some cutscenes were changed, and while the visuals are praised, many players have criticized the reduced difficulty‚Äîespecially in Survival mode, where resources are more abundant.

The story takes place in 2033, after a nuclear war in 2013 forced Moscow‚Äôs survivors into the metro tunnels. You play as Artyom, a young man trying to reach the central Polis station to seek help from the Rangers as his home station is threatened by mysterious creatures called the Dark Ones.

The game blends FPS action with strong survival elements. Military-grade bullets serve as currency, used to buy weapons, gear, filters, and supplies. Resource scarcity depends on the chosen mode: Survival makes scavenging tougher, while Spartan offers a more action-oriented experience.

Across its 10‚Äì13-hour campaign, the game offers a varied arsenal, though aiming can feel slow and many weapons are old-fashioned, with some requiring manual pumping. The atmosphere is exceptional‚Äîrain blurs your mask, insects crawl across it, fog thickens the air, and you often have to wipe away blood or grime mid-fight. The soundtrack enhances the cinematic feel with high-quality, immersive audio.

Metro 2033 Redux combines the mood of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. and Fallout, offering enclosed yet richly explorable environments, two modes, and two endings. With its detailed world and storytelling, it‚Äôs a highly recommended title that deserves a place in any game library.

SO good. I wouldn't say its the best in the trilogy (given exodus exists) but it deserves so much love. the story is linear and straight forward, but thats not necessarily a bad thing, nearing the end you can make a number of choices that impact the ending you get.

The gunplay feels heavy, responsive and bulky, the guns are very cool and have a surprising amount of mechanics, which I feel was a massive win on the game's part. The game is set on an apocalyptic world, conventional weapons run dry, and people have to get creative to protect themselves and others, but also, people have to create different types of weapons, all for different purposes

For example, you have pneumatic weapons that operate on a "pressure" system that only take a certain type of ammo, assault rifles that take normal ammo and military grade, SO MANY SHOTGUN OPTIONS

By far my favorite part of the game are the shotguns; revolver shotguns, double barrel shotguns, quad barrel shotguns, pump shotguns, regular shotguns, pressure shotguns, buckshot shotguns, and even more

But what makes the game so good is not the gunplay or its choice making, but its atmosphere
GOD this game is beautiful and you definitely wouldnt expect this from a 2013 game, the world building is amazing, the world itself feels hostile and unwelcoming, the monsters appear from seemingly nowhere which builds this tension that makes you feel like you could die at any moment if you're not careful

Despite the context of the game and the setting, the game's atmosphere doesn't feel dead by any means, infact I'd say it feels more "alive" than alot of other games you can compare it to.
But the reason why it feels "alive" isnt because it because it makes you feel safe or at peace, but rather because its actively trying to kill you, adding another layer of depth which revolves around insecurity and the ambient's hostility towards you

TL;DR, this game is GREAT and YOU should PLAY IT but only when its on sale because its pretty expensive (I got it on sale and they go for like 80% off, its a steal)

I'd like to start this with METRO 2033 HAS A LOT OF PROBLEMS. However, to be frank, it is easily one of the best post apocalyptic games I've ever played. One of the few games I've ever played that is actually worth playing on its hardest difficulty, Ranger Hardcore. Gameplay is floaty and weird, using throwing knives sucks even tho they are good, stealth is medicore at best, story can be awkward sometimes with what I assume is just the english dub being just ok. The reason you play this game though is its NEAR PERFECT world design. Few apocalypse games really make the outside world feel completely hostile. This is a game where you are not "taking" anything back, you are not going to fix the world. On the surface, you are swarmed by enemies, ammo management, air management, trying to find MGR (military grade round), etc. Even though it's dangerous the game heavily rewards you for exploring and I really appreciate that. The best way to play this game is gamma bar almost completely to the left and getting the NVG's as soon as possible. The scope of this games story is fantastic, if you did more as the main character it would be too much. The terrible morality system of Metro games does not affect this title as much because the cannon ending is the "bad" ending so you don't have to fight with the games horrible "choice" system. The gun economy is also near perfect, mostly there is a distinct difference between weapons. Peak loadout (for Ranger Hardcore) is the Shambler (worth buying asap) and keeping bourbons AK but if you want supreme accuracy and a silencer than VSV is best. Stealth (even though its jank) is the best way to experience human encounters. Shambler is peak weapon design and is significantly better than any other shotgun. Its hard to explain but there is a grimy, grounded uhhhh realistic-ness to Metro? It is unapologetic about what it is and you rarely feel like you are "winning". The spooky atmosphere with ghosts and other-worldly beings make you feel so small in this dying world. If you even kind of like apocalypse games Metro 2033 is a must play. 

8/10

Metro 2033 Redux is a remake of the first game in the Metro series, based on the worldwide bestseller novel by Dmitry Glukhovsky. The story of Metro games is set in a post-apocalyptic future in (or rather, beneath) the Russian capitol of Moscow. A once proud city inhabited by 15 million people has been reduced to ash and rubble in a nuclear war, along with the rest of the civilized world. Those lucky few who survived the devastation have been forced to continue their lives underground, since the irradiated surface was no longer inhabitable. In the tunnels of Moscow underground railway network, often called the Metro, stand the last remnants of human civilization, quite possibly in the entire world.
You are Artyom, a young man who was born in the Metro and has lived his entire life without ever seeing the sky. In fact, you've never ventured much beyond your home station Expedition for the fear of mutants, radiation, unexplained anomalies and million other things that could be fatal in these tunnels. Your life in the Metro is about to change drastically when a certain member of the Spartans, an elite squad of Metro militia, arrives at the Expedition station one day.
When you start playing Metro 2033 Redux, you'll be asked to choose between two campaign modes: the Survival mode or the more-action oriented Spartan mode. I've tried both modes and I can say that they are both good in their own way. In general terms, Metro 2033 is a horror-shooter with survival elements and a strong atmosphere. The campaign includes a series of chapters with mostly linear, but well-rounded and enjoyable gameplay. The storyline is solid as well, I'd say well above average for a FPS game. The only thing about gameplay that I dislike is the inability to backtrack within a chapter - once you get past a certain point, you cannot go back. When you take into account that autosave is the only way to save the game, you'll be sure to miss out on some of the content.
In terms of presentation, this Redux remake looks like a modern game, with advanced physics, better lighting and weather effects and, most importantly, more detailed textures. The only real giveaway that you're playing a 15-year-old game is the NPC facial features design - your comrades' faces look outdated and a bit disfigured. The background music and sound effects fit the game atmosphere really well, strengthening the feeling of isolation in a nuclear wasteland. Though I did run into an annoying audio bug ‚Äî when you‚Äôre in a station surrounded by crowds of people, everyone tends to talk at once, creating a chaotic jumble of sound that‚Äôs almost impossible to understand. I've encountered several other bugs as well, even a game-breaking one that has forced me to restart the chapter. Even so, I had a great time playing through the game.

I was very pleasantly surprised by Metro 2033 Redux. I went in with low expectations, but after finishing it, I can confidently say it‚Äôs among the best single-player FPS games I‚Äôve ever played.

Metro 2033 Redux is a relentless, claustrophobic, and stress-inducing experience stuffed into Moscow's Metro tunnels. The earth being a desolate landscape is not a new setting in games, but this one truly sells the sheer cost of existence. Every breath, every bullet, and every clumsy step, even above ground, is weighted with panic.

The metro is very linear, but the moment you set foot on the surface, all of that just fucks off the second your foot crunches some glass, dragging a pack of hideous Nosalises straight to your location. That panic is intense. Yes, there is a Point A to Point B, but when my heartrate spikes? I will wind up running into a wall, or stopping at a deadend, and I will die.

I grew up playing more arcade-y shooters like Call of Duty, and Battlefield. I constantly had to fight the urge to run in and light a room up, but Metro 2033 Redux quickly taught me that recklessness means you just burned a clip of precious, irreplaceable military-grade ammunition. And that, absolutely fucking sucks.

Choosing Survival Ranger difficulty was absolutely the move, even if it turned my whole trip into an unforgiving lesson in getting my ass beat. I don't play games like these, so it was very new to me. Every encounter feels high-stakes. I try to be stealthy, taking out lights and dropping guys with a throwing knife. The thing is, I'm terrible at stealth, and one tiny screw-up, like sprinting when I'm not supposed to, or a misjudged timing to cross a path, then suddenly I'm in a firefight for my life, burning resources like an idiot. The real tension isn't the monsters; it's the genuine, sickening realization that a single fuck-up just cost me my last magazine for my automatic weapon, or half my medkits. So then I just have to live with the consequences of my now depleted resources.

The game's central mission to warn Polis about the Dark Ones honestly felt secondary to the sheer immersion of the environment. The main plot is simple, and that‚Äôs fine, but the real meat is in the world itself: the sad pig farms, the bustling but desperate markets, the desperate chatter of the survivors. The world-building is so captivating that the Dark One plot winds up on the backburner up until the very end. However, the human drama, and the moment-to-moment scavenging provide a much richer, more complex narrative experience.

Even after achieving the ending where the missile strike goes ahead, the ambiguity and eventual sympathy for the Dark Ones lingered. To me, it speaks to the game's atmosphere that the human struggles provide a much richer, more complex narrative experience than the main threat.

Metro 2033 Redux is dark, and it's challenging. Every mistake makes me feel like shit, and I yelped at far too many jumpscares than I should have. All things considered, it was pretty fun. Now on to Last Light.

This game is a hilarious exercise in patience. I am four hours in, and still, a majority of the 'gameplay' is scripted exposition, outpost trawling, and functional escort missions. The gunplay is fun, I just wish I got to do more of it.
